text: I think we've been running this particular strategy formally for, I want to say it's at least seven years. We've never actually held a portfolio that looks like our benchmark ever. I think except for one year, we actually delivered returns that were above the benchmark. We did have a couple of drawdowns that were not pleasant. But I think one of the ways that you do this is you look at decision and you say, hey, the people who move quickly, where are they concentrated, right? Because you don't necessarily want to be concentrated where they are. And if CTAs are, I'm going to use an example that is timely to when we're recording this, but CTAs right now are extremely short treasuries. The trend has been really strong. The prices have been cratering week after week, and that's delivered signals to them that they should follow the trend. And the way that they position a lot of times is they pyramid. That means that they increase their position every time the trend is confirmed. And so the more the trend goes, the bigger their position becomes. So I look at that. And they say, hey, I may not love where interest rates are right now relative to our expectations of forward growth and inflation, but these people can and will change their positioning on a dime. And they could go from being short $50 billion of 10-year equivalents to being long $50 billion of 10-year equivalents in the matter of a few weeks. The same thing where you get the fast-moving retail crowd, especially the people that are looking for active stories, trends that are moving, places where they're getting the volatility that they need to get that exciting trading that they find that fills their interest and the risk profile that they seek. And we say, well, do we really want to be in here? Do we really want our short-term performance to be predicated on whether this stock is still considered hot by the people who are on these investing forums or mailing lists or whatever? We look at the hedge fund, the so-called hedge fund hotels, right? Where, well, you know, if all of these hedge funds are extremely long, these names, you're, in large size, well, who's the exit? Like, who are they going to sell to? And it becomes this kind of approach. We're not building a portfolio from scratch. We're taking a portfolio and we're hacking pieces away. And one of the things that we've found is that through the magic of statistics, one of your other guests could probably explain this very well. I'm not the person for that. It's actually really hard to deviate substantially from a benchmark if you have a big enough sample. And that sample doesn't have to be that big. As long as you're sampling across sectors, you're going to do pretty good. And even within sectors, if you look at the historical returns of an equal weighted and market cap weighted index, you'll find that they go through periods where one of them outperforms the other. But ultimately, they just kind of end up coming back to having the same returns. You look at the returns of mid cap versus small cap, you find the same things. Obviously, there's some places where you're not going to... Where that's going to be impossible just because the structure at the firm level is different. And so that's not going to happen. But once you kind of accept the fact that if you have a big enough sample, over time, it's going to be very hard to deviate, then you can feel a lot more comfortable in just hacking things out of your portfolio. It's like, do you really need a bunch of investment grade corporates that are leaving you a few basis points of extra spread? I mean... I don't think so. I mean, I think that sometimes there's a use for them. And we have these big market portfolios that include the fixed income, the ag, which was a big ball of noise. And on the equity side, you have a market cap weighted index. And you can feel free to just take entire sectors out. I mean, we do it all the time. I mean, right now, we're running a grand total of three sectors and that's it. And once you kind of understand the individual drivers of these sectors, and we can talk about this more... You can start feeling really comfortable in building these portfolios by looking at them and saying, hey, okay, the index is giving me these risk scores. And so right now, I think that a broad market cap weighted index has a left tail where you could possibly lose 70%. And then you can drill down and say, okay, well, where is the risk coming from? Right? And sometimes it'll come from a sector, sometimes it'll come from a factor. And you can get to these places where you can just kind of like chop one out and be like, okay, you don't want this? All right. I realize there's probably not enough risk going in but let's try this one here. Where's my einfachity? Where's my every decision and my every decision is effective? When can each opportunity come in like underwater? Oh, well, depending on what you're building. So that's, that's it. Sort of the second example is that which means you may have different options foriska in physical writes, even though it's not obvious in processing or JW , for the most part, because you say, Hey, this seems essential to me too. And you can still put Koran on that sagte to it. Kirill Karimov. kind of classification system. And there's lots of these risks there where they're correlated enough and they co-integrate relatively well. And you can trade back between banks and insurance and utilities and staples. It'll be fine, energy and basic materials. And I think that's kind of how you use all of these ideas to build portfolios. You say, hey, what am I really not willing to do? And for example, for us recently, it was like, well, I'm not willing to take that small probability of taking a very nasty loss if all of a sudden retail traders decide that, hey, I need to focus on my job. I got taxes to pay. I got kids that are going back to school. I don't have time to be sitting around day trading all day. You have the sudden loss of interest, and then who's the bid for a lot of this stuff? And I like to say, it's a long way from growth to value. So- That's essentially how we use it in practice. We look at where we see an intersection of risks that we find higher than we necessarily need and where the positioning tells us that maybe it's not the right time to take that risk.
